ATbar

ATbar is an Open Source browser toolbar that allows you to change the look and feel of webpages. It is designed for those who may not have their assistive technologies to hand and need a quick way of accessing text on the screen with magnification and/or text to speech etc. It can help those with low vision, dyslexia and other reading difficulties, as well as those who may wish to just reduce the glare of black text on bright white backgrounds. It is not designed for regular screen reader users who need their assistive technology to access the computer as well as their browser.

Azure Dev Tools for Teaching

Microsoft's Azure Dev Tools for Teaching program replaces the Microsoft Imagine offer and provides University students and staff who are involved in teaching or non-commercial research, access to professional developer and designer tools at no charge, for educational use*.

STEM use only

Only staff/faculty and students from STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics) departments are eligible to download and install software from Azure Dev Tools for Teaching. You must therefore be from one of these departments.

Before downloading, you are strongly advised to read the permitted use cases and terms and conditions.

What software is available?

A number of Microsoft applications are available, including Visio, Project and Visual Studio. Please see the FAQs for a complete list.

How can I access the software?

Managed Machines

You will NOT be able to install this software on a managed desktop. If you need the software on a managed desktop, please contact the ITS Help Desk.

Unmanaged Machines

  • Go to the Azure Dev Tools for Teaching website.
  • Click Sign In.
  • Sign in with your University Microsoft Office 365 email address (in the format usercode@live.warwick.ac.uk) and your normal University password.
  • When prompted, select the 'work or school account option'.
  • You will then be taken to Warwick's external service sign in page. Sign in with your IT Services username and password.
  • You should then be taken to the Azure Dev Tools for Teaching portal. Click the 'Software' tab and you should be shown a list of available software downloads.

For more information please see the Azure Dev Tools for Teaching page.

Dragon Naturally Speaking

Although there is no site licence available for the speech-recognition software, Dragon Naturally Speaking, at Warwick, there are some options to access the software:

Purchase a licence on a departmental cost code via IT Services

Dragon Naturally Speaking is pre-approved for use at Warwick and so you do not need to complete a software approval form for this. If your department is willing to purchase a licence for you, IDG will order this for you on your cost code. Please log the request with the IT Services Help Desk, providing your cost code.

Dragon in the Library:

The Library makes Dragon and other assistive software available in their Accessible study rooms. Please click here for details.

Request a HR referral to Occupational Health:

In cases where there is an identified long term/permanent disability requiring voice software, the licence might be funded through a central budget subject to an assessment of needs by the Occupational Health team. If you'd like to explore that option, please follow the Occupational Health Referral process or contact the Occupational Health Resource

Dropbox

The University of Warwick does not support the use of Dropbox. The University has invested in equivalent Microsoft platforms and works closely with its Microsoft partners to ensure the products offer real solutions and remain easy to understand and use.

The Information and Digital Group (IDG) provides a support and training infrastructure for Microsoft OneDrive for Business and associated Microsoft platforms, but there is no support structure for alternative cloud storage platforms, such as Dropbox.

However, there may be some very distinct (non-teaching) situations where you feel OneDrive for Business is not well-suited to your requirements (e.g. for certain external collaboration or research activities, or if you use Linux) and IDG can review the use of Dropbox on a case-by-case basis, via a request for an Exception.

In order for an Exception request to be considered, you must populate the form with as much information as possible, including why OneDrive for Business is not appropriate for your use or situation.

Exceptions are temporary and as such, will usually cover a specified project or event. Exceptions can also be withdrawn as the University reviews its position on the various tools available in this space.

Gale Digital Scholar Lab at Warwick

Gale Digital Scholar Lab at Warwick is a single cloud-based research and learning platform that provides an environment to apply natural language processing (NLP) techniques to raw optical character recognition (OCR) text data from Gales primary data sources or own data. The platform has been designed for researchers, students, teachers, librarians, and digital humanists interested in text mining as well as archival research and analysis methods. Inkscape

Inkscape is a Free and open source vector graphics editor for GNU/Linux, Windows and macOS. It offers a rich set of features and is widely used for both artistic and technical illustrations such as cartoons, clip art, logos, typography, diagramming and flowcharting. It uses vector graphics to allow for sharp printouts and renderings at unlimited resolution and is not bound to a fixed number of pixels like raster graphics. Inkscape uses the standardized SVG file format as its main format, which is supported by many other applications including web browsers.

It can import and export various file formats, including SVG, AI, EPS, PDF, PS and PNG. It has a comprehensive feature set, a simple interface, multi-lingual support and is designed to be extensible; users can customize Inkscape's functionality with add-ons.

Microsoft Visio

Visio is a full-featured diagramming tool that is part of the Microsoft Office family of applications. It fills the gap between PowerPoint and full-blown CAD packages, allowing straightforward creation of organisation, flowchart, room layout diagrams, and technical drawings like network and electrical schematics.

Visio doesn't replace PowerPoint - PowerPoint is straightforward to use for presentation graphics where simplicity is important. Visio is better at more complicated diagrams which need to be altered frequently, like organisation charts.

As a rule of thumb, if PowerPoint produces what you need, carry on using it. If you're frustrated with PowerPoint's abilities, you should try Visio.

What does it work on?

 Windows

How to get it

All Warwick users get access to the web app version of Visio for free via your University Microsoft 365 (aka Office 365) account. Although this is a browser-based, lightweight version of the desktop edition, it still provides much of the core Visio functionality and lets you create, edit, and share professional diagrams. All users should try this before requesting a paid-for Visio Plan 2 subscription.

Zoom

The University of Warwick does not support the use of Zoom. The University has invested in equivalent Microsoft platforms and works closely with its Microsoft partners to ensure the products offer real solutions and remain easy to understand and use.

The Information and Digital Group (IDG) provides a support and training infrastructure for Microsoft Teams and associated MS platforms, but there is no support structure for alternative platforms, such as Zoom.

However, there may be some very distinct situations where Teams is not appropriate for external engagement (i.e. digital events, conferences or research NOT teaching) and IDG can review the use of Zoom on a case-by-case basis, via a request for an Exception.

In order for an Exception request to be considered, you must populate the form with as much information as possible, including why Teams is not appropriate for your use or situation.

Exceptions are temporary and as such, will usually cover a specified event or group of events. Exceptions can also be withdrawn as the University reviews its position on the various tools available in this space.
